sequence.notes: Alpha-alkylation of an enone via its enolate using allyl bromide.

A but-3-enyl Grignard reagent reacts with a 2-allyl-3-methoxycyclohex-2-en-1-one to form a 5-allyl-3-(pent-4-enyl)cyclohex-2-en-1-one, involving substitution of the methoxy group by a lengthened alkenyl chain and a rearrangement of the existing allyl group.
Alpha-allylation of a cyclohexenone via enolate formation.

Nucleophilic addition to the ketone. The reagent shown in the screenshot is TMS-propynal (`TMS-C≡C-CH=O`). However, the product structure shows the addition of a TMS-alkyne fragment (C≡C-TMS) to the ketone, forming a tertiary alcohol. This transformation implies the nucleophile was likely TMS-lithioacetylene (or similar), not the aldehyde shown. The provided reagent SMILES `C[Si](C)(C)C#CC=O` accurately reflects the *drawn* reagent.
1,4-addition of methyl group to cyclohexenone beta-carbon, catalyzed by copper(I).
Dess-Martin oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone.
Desilylation and bromination of a TMS-protected terminal alkyne.

The reaction involves enol silylation of the cyclic ketone to form a cyclohexenyl silyl ether (double bond formed between C1 and C2 of the cyclic ketone, where C1 gets the OTBS group). Simultaneously, the side-chain propargyl ketone is reduced to an alcohol and subsequently silylated with TBS. The stereochemistry of the three existing chiral centers (C3, C5, and C6) is retained, and a new chiral center at the reduced ketone is formed with an 'up' configuration for the OTBS group. 

Note: The product drawing in the screenshot visually depicts the sp2 carbon (C2, using standard cyclohexene numbering) of the double bond as having four substituents (double bond to C1, single bond to C3, allyl group, and the reduced propargyl chain), which is chemically impossible for an sp2 carbon. The provided SMILES reflects the most chemically plausible interpretation of the intended product structure, where the double bond is formed between the ketone carbon and the less substituted alpha carbon (C1=C2), allowing the adjacent chiral center (C6) to retain its two substituents (allyl and reduced propargyl chain).
Intramolecular gold-catalyzed cascade reaction involving alkyne activation, allene formation, and subsequent cyclizations to form a complex polycyclic structure. Two OTBS groups are lost.
Nucleophilic substitution of a vinyl bromide with methoxide on an enone system.

sequence.reaction_type: Silyl enol ether formation / Silylation of vinyl proton
sequence.notes: Deprotonation of the vinyl proton adjacent to the ketone and enol ether by LiHMDS, followed by trapping with TMSCl to form a silyl enol ether.
Alpha-iodination of the enol ether moiety, replacing a hydrogen with an iodine atom at the chiral bridgehead position. The reaction proceeds with LDA, TMSCl, and I2.
Lithium-halogen exchange followed by nucleophilic addition of organolithium to isobutyraldehyde.
Oxidation of a secondary alcohol to a ketone.
Desilylation of a silyl enol ether with TBAF to form an enol ether. The core structure is a complex polycycle, a derivative of Hyperforin.

Alkylation of an enolized 1,3-diketone system. A pent-4-enyl group is added to the enone moiety. There is a discrepancy: the drawn reagent is allyl bromide (3C), but the product shows addition of a pent-4-enyl group (4C). The SMILES for the drawn reagent (allyl bromide) is provided.

A cross-metathesis reaction with isobutylene (C=C(C)C) is performed on the reactant, which contains three terminal but-3-enyl groups and one allyl group. All terminal alkenes are converted into more substituted internal alkenes. The three but-3-enyl groups are transformed into 4-methylpent-3-enyl groups, and the allyl group is transformed into a 3-methylbut-2-enyl (prenyl) group. Stereochemistry, as indicated by bold bonds in the core structure, is preserved.
